Name: Microcystin-LR
Description: Microcystin-LR is a microcystin consisting of D-alanyl, L-leucyl, (3S)-3-methyl-D-beta-aspartyl,L-arginyl, 2S,3S,4E,6E,8S,9S)-3-amino-4,5,6,7-tetradehydro-9-methoxy-2,6,8-trimethyl-10-phenyldecanoyl, D-gamma-glutamyl, and 2,3-didehydro-N-methylalanyl residues joined into a 25-membered macrocycle. Produced by the cyanobacterium Microcystis aeruginosa, it is the most studied of the microcystins. It has a role as a bacterial metabolite, an EC 3.1.3.16 (phosphoprotein phosphatase) inhibitor, a xenobiotic and an environmental contaminant.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Xiao FG et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 57: 256 (2009). Available from, as of January 16, 2019: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00244-008-9275-6
plant_concentrations.Value: Microcystins were detected in 6 out of 18 water chestnut samples collected from Lake Tai, China in October 2007, with the maximum concentration reported at 7.02 ng/g. Microcystin-LR was reported at a maximum concentration of 1.02 ng/g, and was detected in 5 of the samples(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Berry JP et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 30(7): 1621-1628 (2011)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Samples of zooplanktivorous fish commonly consumed in the Lago de Patzcuaro lake area were collected from a local market, consisting of uncooked, fried, and dried fish samples and assessed for the presence of microcystins. All samples were reported under the laboratory detection limit of 0.15 parts per billion. Samples of fish, consisting of zooplanktivorous, phytoplanktivorous, and omnivorous fish, commonly consumed in Michoacan, Mexico were collected from commercial fishing operations that occurred within the Lago de Patzcuaro in the vicinity of cyanobacterial blooms. Total microcystin concentrations ranged from 4.99 ng/g in the dorsal muscle to 867 ng/g in the viscera/liver(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Jia J et al; Sci Total Environ 487: 224-232 (2014)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Forty-six fish samples, including two species of phytoplanktivores and two species of omnivores, were collected from Lake Taihu, located in eastern China, in 2011, and assessed for the presence of microcystin-LR in the muscles, liver, kidney, and intestinal wall. Average concentrations of microcystin-LR were reported at 0 ng/g in the heart of all four species of carp assessed in this study(1).
